    • Method Detail

      • closeQuietly

        public static void closeQuietly(AutoCloseable resource,
                                Consumer<Throwable> consumer)
        Closes an AutoCloseable resource, with explicit control over how to handle any error that may occur.

        This is primarily useful when manually cleaning up resources, where a thrown exception needs to be logged, suppressed, or otherwise handled without being propagated.

        Discussion: Common closeQuietly implementations generally fall into two categories:

        • They silently ignore any Exception that occurs during the closing process. While seemingly convenient, this can mask critical errors, especially when writing to an I/O resource where data loss or corruption might occur without any indication.
        • They log any closing exception using java.util.logging. This approach is preferable because it acknowledges the error, but it lacks flexibility, as the user has no direct control over the logger configuration or the handling of the logged exception.

        In contrast, this method allows the user to provide a Consumer that will be invoked with any error thrown by the close() method. This enables you to implement custom error logging, reporting, or recovery mechanisms tailored to your specific application needs.

        Parameters:
        resource - the AutoCloseable resource to close or null in which case this method is a no-op
        consumer - the exception handler to use
